segments.key_quote: Maharaj Parikshit, therefore, like his grandfather Arjuna, collected all illicit gold kept for the propensities of Kali and employed it for the purpose of and employed it in the Sankirtan Yajna as per the instruction of the Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Parikshit Maharaj, like Arjuna, used illicit gold for Sankirtan Yajna, which is the recommended Yajna for Kali Yuga.
segments.transcript: becomes lost. So, Srila Prabhupada says, specifically what did he do? Maharaj Parikshit, therefore, like his grandfather Arjuna, collected all illicit gold kept for the propensities of Kali and employed it for the purpose of and employed it in the Sankirtan Yajna as per the instruction of the Srimad Bhagavatam. Bhagavatam says, in Kali Yuga, other types of Yajna are not practical. In the Bhagavad Gita and all the scriptures it is said, work should be done as Yajna so that people don't become entangled in this material world. So, there are varieties of Yajna that one may perform, but in Kali Yuga, the most practical and feasible type of Yajna is Sankirtan Yajna. So therefore, Parikshit Maharaj, like his grandfather, Arjuna, he employed all the illicit gold kept for propensities of Kali. Illicit gold means gold that has been accumulated for sense enjoyment that he utilized in Sankirtan Yajna.

segments.key_quote: Namely, 50% for the service of the Lord. Lord means the Supreme Lord Krishna. 25% for the family members. And 25% for personal necessities.
segments.summary: The speaker shares Prabhupada's recommendation for dividing excess wealth: 50% for Krishna's service, 25% for family, and 25% for personal needs.
segments.transcript: And that is a recommendation of the Bhagavatam. As we have suggested before, Prabhupada gave instructions in a previous purport that I read in detail, the 38th verse purport. It is very big. We covered it in three sessions, three parts. And there, one of the recommendations Prabhupada had given that once accumulated wealth may be divided into three parts for distribution. Namely, 50% for the service of the Lord. Lord means the Supreme Lord Krishna. 25% for the family members. And 25% for personal necessities. So, dividing one's wealth. This for whom? Particularly for people who have lot of excess wealth than what is bare minimum required for keeping body and soul together. There are those who live by the principle that, I will only take as much wealth as is necessary for the minimum, bare minimum necessities for maintaining this body while in the material world because my main business will be simply to engage in Krishna consciousness. For such people, there is no need of any such business division to be made because they don't have that for dividing like this but for those who are having excess wealth than what is minimum necessary there is a a way of dividing the wealth into three parts what is that 50% for service of Krishna 25% for the family members

segments.key_quote: Spending 50% of the service of the Lord or for propagation of spiritual knowledge in society by way of the Sankirtan Yagna is the maximum display of human mercy this is actually a necessity for the human beings in the human society
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of using wealth for Sankirtan Yajna as the greatest act of mercy, enabling people to achieve their human mission and return to Godhead.
